articles.title: JUNE 1987
articles.summary: This document outlines the schedule of events for June and July 1987, organized by the SJAA. Key activities include a general meeting featuring a talk on UFOs, board meetings, an indoor astronomy class, several field expeditions for astronomical observation at Fremont Peak and Grant Ranch, and an annual membership picnic culminating in a star party.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: The article outlines upcoming events for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), including a June 6th general meeting featuring Tom Gates discussing UFOs, and the annual picnic and star party on July 18th at Grant Ranch County Park. It also details a multi-day Yosemite Glacier Point Star Party and camping trip, encouraging members to register, bring telescopes for public viewing, and volunteer for activities like a slideshow.

articles.title: TOOK TWO SHOTS, GOT NO DUCKS
articles.summary: At a Fremont Peak star party, the author humorously encountered a "useless" Takahashi tripod leveling accessory, dubbed "duck feet." These oversized, hinged aluminum plates provided minimal leveling adjustment, leading the author to mock their impracticality and the manufacturer's design choices for a product seemingly designed for an already level surface.

articles.title: EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES
articles.summary: Orion Telescope Center is opening a new astronomy store in Cupertino early this Summer and is actively seeking full-time and part-time Customer Service Representatives. Interested applicants should send their inquiries to David English, Customer Service Manager, at the provided Santa Cruz address.

articles.title: GRANT RANCH STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) is hosting star parties at Grant Ranch County Park, offering a convenient, close-to-home observing location. The article provides detailed directions to the park, located on Mt. Hamilton Road, along with essential access information including the gate combination (4585) and instructions to lock the gate upon entry and exit to reach the designated equipment setup area.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: A new C90 Astro Telescope, complete with a single mount, star diagonal, two eyepieces, a 5x24 finder, and a dew shield, is advertised for sale. The telescope is unused and still in its original shipping cartons, priced at $400 or best offer.

articles.title: YOSEMITE GLACIER POINT STAR PARTY -- SJAA CAMPING REGISTRATION FORM
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) is hosting a star party at Yosemite National Park's Glacier Point during the August 22nd weekend, inviting members to present astronomical observations for park guests under favorable conditions. Free group camping for up to 30 people is available at Bridalveil Creek Campground for registered participants, who must comply with park rules regarding telescopes and vehicle parking. Interested members are required to complete and return a registration form to John Gleason.

articles.title: BY: JAY REYNOLDS FREEMAN
articles.summary: Jay Reynolds Freeman recounts his first experience with Kevin Medlock's 30-inch Newtonian telescope at Fremont Peak Observatory, praising its powerful views but detailing significant logistical challenges. He identifies issues with finding objects, observer stability due to climbing ladders, and the need for multiple people to operate the large instrument efficiently. Freeman suggests design improvements like powered observing chairs or better finder placement, with the editor concurring about the ladder issue and mentioning a new platform for groups, while also soliciting donations for finder scopes.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: Don Machholz reports on the recent recovery of several faint periodic comets, including Howell (1987h), d'Arrest (1987k), Reinmuth 2 (1987L), and Brooks 2 (1987M), detailing their discovery, current magnitudes, and expected brightness. The article also briefly mentions other bright comets in the sky and the fading of Halley's Comet. Additionally, it provides information about the Comet Rapid Announcement Service (CRAS) for comet enthusiasts.

articles.title: EPHEMERIDES
articles.summary: This document provides ephemerides for four comets—Comet Sorrells (1986v), Comet Nishikawa-Takamizawa-Tago (1987c), Comet Wilson (1986L), and Periodic Comet Halley (1982i)—for dates spanning May 25 to July 4. It includes their right ascension, declination, elongation, and magnitude, along with descriptive notes on their orbital characteristics, visibility, distances, and sky movements for observers.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: This article details specific exceptions and conventions for naming comets, particularly concerning the discoverers' names. It explains how periodic comets found by the same person are numbered, how married couples use a single last name for a comet, and how hyphenated or multi-part names (like "Singer-Brewster" or "van Biesbroeck") are handled. The text provides various examples to clarify these nuanced rules in comet nomenclature.

articles.title: SPACE SHUTTLE RECOVERY EFFORT IS PROGRESSING
articles.summary: The Space Shuttle recovery effort is progressing, with the solid booster redesign complete and sub-scale testing finished; full-scale firing is scheduled for May. NASA has updated the flight resumption target to April 1988, citing a new tank test and readiness firing needs, while a contractor assessment predicts readiness by September 1988.

articles.title: SPACE STATION PROGRAM IS SHAKY BUT STILL ALIVE
articles.summary: The Space Station Program recently faced a political crisis where a Department of Defense power play almost led to international partners withdrawing, only for NASA's firm stance to resolve the immediate conflict. Despite lingering political tensions, NASA has advanced with requests for hardware proposals, announcing program changes including an electrical power upgrade and an accelerated deployment schedule, targeting permanently manned capability by late 1995.

articles.title: THE VALUE OF MAN IN SPACE IS PROVED AGAIN
articles.summary: The Kvant x-ray astrophysics module experienced initial difficulties docking with the Mir space station, with a forgotten bag preventing proper electrical connections. Cosmonauts performed a spacewalk to manually remove the obstruction, enabling a successful docking and electrical hookup. This human intervention ultimately facilitated the first-ever four-vehicle hookup in space with the subsequent arrival of a Progress resupply tanker.

articles.title: U.S. AND USSR HAVING LAUNCH PROBLEMS
articles.summary: Both the U.S. and USSR recently experienced significant launch failures. The U.S. lost an Atlas Centaur carrying a Fleet Satellite Communications spacecraft on March 26th due to a lightning strike. The Soviets, on April 24th, also lost a Proton booster carrying three large navigation satellites, marking their second such failure.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ AND RICH PAGE
articles.summary: This article describes a quiet, low-traffic stargazing site on Weaver Road above Lexington Reservoir, near San Jose. Located at 1600 feet, it offers good visibility above valley haze with a limiting naked-eye magnitude of 5.8, despite some light pollution and occasional adverse weather. The site, suitable for about five vehicles and telescopes, is presented as a convenient and potentially favorite spot for local astronomers.

articles.title: FIRST NAVSTAR SATELLITE DELIVERED
articles.summary: The first Navstar global positioning system satellite has been delivered to the Air Force. This spacecraft will be stored until the new Delta 2 booster becomes available in October 1988 for its eventual launch.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings at the Los Gatos Red Cross building on the 4th Saturday of each month, starting at 8 PM. These meetings, which also host "Indoor Star Parties," offer a friendly atmosphere for members to share interests in astrophotography, deep sky observation, telescope making, and general astronomy. The article provides detailed directions to the venue.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: The article describes monthly "Indoor Star Parties" hosted by an astronomy organization, providing an informal gathering for amateur astronomers. Attendees are encouraged to bring telescopes and binoculars to share, with activities including outdoor observing, astrophotography slideshows, and an introductory astronomy workshop. These events, held at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building, also serve as a venue for board meetings and social interaction.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK
articles.summary: This document provides directions to Henry Coe State Park, guiding visitors from Hwy 101 to a specific observing site. It details access to the site via a locked gate, providing the club combination and emphasizing the importance of re-locking. Additionally, it offers crucial advice for those arriving after dark, recommending parking outside the gate and hiking in to find a suitable observing spot.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: The article provides detailed directions to Fremont Peak State Park, highlighting it as a popular astronomical observing site often frequented by the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) during clear new moon weekends. It also mentions the Fremont Peak Observatory Association's (FPOA) public observatory located there, accommodating numerous telescopes. Additionally, the document includes publication information for the SJAA's monthly 'EPHEMERIS' newsletter and lists the association's current officers and board members with contact details.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It details different membership tiers, including options for individual membership, membership with a Sky & Telescope subscription, and a junior membership, each with its associated cost. The form also provides submission instructions, including a mailing address and contact information for the association's treasurer.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document is an optional questionnaire designed to solicit information regarding individuals' astronomical interests, whether they own a telescope, and specific areas of astronomy in which they feel qualified to assist others. It also includes mailing information for SJAA EPHEMERIS, a non-profit organization in San Jose, CA, and is marked as time-sensitive news material.
